title: 108_hr4105
content: The Act may be cited as the "Domestic Violence Connections Campaign Act of 2004". Congress finds that the National Domestic Violence Hotline provides immediate, confidential assistance to over 500 individuals daily, with bilingual staff and access to translators in 150 languages. The hotline connects callers with over 5,000 shelters and service providers in the US, Puerto Rico, and the US Virgin Islands for crisis intervention. The National Domestic Violence Hotline in Austin, Texas, received its first call in 1996 and reached its one millionth call in 2003. Approximately 60% of callers use the hotline as their first step in addressing domestic violence. Call volume increased by 27% between 2000 and 2003, with 26,000 calls going unanswered in 2002 due to high demand. The Department of Justice reported over 18,000 acts of violence by intimate partners in the United States. An average of 3 women are murdered every day in the United States by their intimate partners. Improving technology infrastructure at the National Domestic Violence Hotline and forming partnerships between the public and private sectors can enhance the hotline's ability to handle more calls efficiently. The Connections Campaign aims to unite efforts in addressing domestic violence. The Connections Campaign unites nonprofit organizations, major corporations, and Federal agencies to upgrade technology at the National Domestic Violence Hotline for better call handling. The Attorney General will award a grant to the National Domestic Violence Hotline for technology and telecommunication training. The grant aims to improve equipment through the Connections Campaign. Additionally, a research grant will be provided to study the Hotline. The Attorney General will award a grant to a university or research institution to study the National Domestic Violence Hotline, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Hotline. Applications for the grant must be submitted with required information. The study on the National Domestic Violence Hotline will compile statistical information about calls received, interpret trends and gaps in services, and gather important data on domestic violence. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 3 years of the Act's enactment. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress and the Attorney General. SEC. 5. Grant authorized for public awareness campaign on domestic violence issues in consultation with relevant organizations. Organizations must apply for the grant with required information. SEC. 6. Authorization of appropriations. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2005 and 2006 totaling $1.55 million for specific sections. Funds remain available until expended, and the National Domestic Violence Hotline is not limited in seeking additional federal funding. Appropriated amounts are not subject to certain conditions under the Family Violence Prevention and Services Act.
